Introduction

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor in infants.  The classic inspiratory stridor results from the dynamic collapse of the supraglottic structures during inspiration due to the structural and functional immaturity of the larynx.  Although most cases are mild and self-limited, some infants may develop feeding difficulties, respiratory distress, or failure to thrive.

Pathogenesis

Dynamic changes to the airway caliber occur with inspiration and expiration due to pressure differentials created by airflow.  During inspiration, faster airflow causes decreased intraluminal pressure in the airways (eg, decreased intralaryngeal pressure).  In patients with a more collapsible extrathoracic airway (eg, laryngomalacia), the decreased pressure inferior to the larynx leads to increased airway narrowing, resulting in turbulent flow and inspiratory stridor (

figure 1
).  Any increase in breathing effort (eg, due to feeding, crying) increases airflow, worsens supraglottic collapse, and increases stridor.

Although the etiology of supraglottic tissue collapse (causing the "floppy" larynx) is not known, etiologies may include:

  • Laryngeal hypotonia:  Delayed maturation of neurologic coordination can occur due to abnormal sensorimotor integration.
  • Redundant soft tissue and/or decreased cartilaginous support:  Immature cartilage leads to decreased cartilage framework support.  Redundant soft tissue can become too large or heavy for the cartilaginous support structure.
  • Inflammation:  Gastroesophageal reflux can lead to increased bulk of soft tissues and softening of the cartilage.  Of note, nearly all patients with laryngomalacia have gastroesophageal reflux; however, it is unclear if this causes laryngomalacia or if the conditions have a common underlying etiology.

Risk factors

  • Gastroesophageal reflux.
  • Low birth weight (including prematurity and fetal growth restriction).
  • Neuromuscular disorders (eg, cerebral palsy, hypotonia).

Clinical presentation

Stridor from laryngomalacia usually begins in the neonatal period and is loudest at age 4-8 months.  Patients have chronic or recurrent inspiratory stridor that varies in severity.  It is worsened by:

  • Supine positioning.
  • Feeding.
  • Upper respiratory illnesses.
  • Crying or agitation.

A spectrum of severity is observed.  Although many infants have noisy breathing with few consequences, stridor can lead to feeding difficulties, which can cause poor weight gain, respiratory distress, and failure to thrive (from a combination of feeding difficulties and respiratory distress).

Differential diagnosis

The differential diagnosis of laryngomalacia includes other causes of stridor in infants and toddlers, including (

):

  • Foreign body aspiration:  A foreign body in the trachea or main bronchus can cause acute respiratory distress, cyanosis, and stridor; a foreign body in the lower airway can lead to chronic or recurrent cough.  Patients often have focal, unilateral wheezing and decreased breath sounds with a prolonged expiratory phase (due to distal air trapping).
  • Vocal cord paralysis:  Normally, vocal cords open for breathing and close for talking or swallowing.  Paralysis of one or both cords leads to fixed obstruction at the level of the glottis.  This presents with biphasic stridor, a weak cry, and, often, aspiration (due to a decreased ability to protect the airway).
  • Tracheomalacia:  Pediatric tracheomalacia is usually due to poor cartilaginous support of the large airways.  The flaccidity of the large airways in the trachea leads to increased collapse during periods of increased intrathoracic pressure (eg, during expiration).  Patients have expiratory wheezing that worsens with effort (eg, crying).
  • Vascular ring (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ):  A condition in which congenital malformations of the great vessels surround and compress the trachea (
    figure 2
    ).  Patients with a vascular ring classically have esophageal compression and a biphasic stridor that improves with neck extension.
  • Airway hemangioma:  Vascular malformation of the subglottic trachea and/or larynx that grows in the first few weeks of life, leading to progressive biphasic stridor.  In addition, many patients have concurrent skin hemangiomas in a beard distribution.

Diagnosis

The diagnosis of laryngomalacia is based on observation of the typical stridor pattern and findings on flexible laryngoscopy (

figure 3
), which is performed in awake infants to visualize the dynamic function of the supraglottic airway.  Findings consistent with laryngomalacia include:

  • Omega-shaped (folded or curled) epiglottis.
  • Redundant aryepiglottic folds, which collapse inward.
  • Soft, immature cartilage in the supraglottic structures.

These findings result in dynamic airway collapse during inspiration.

Laryngomalacia can have a wide range of severity.  Mild cases can be diagnosed and managed in the outpatient setting.  In contrast, severe cases (eg, desaturation, poor feeding, poor growth) may require hospitalization.  Additional evaluation may be required for more severe or inconclusive cases and can include:

  • Airway fluoroscopy to evaluate for tracheomalacia or vascular rings.
  • Videofluoroscopic swallow study (eg, modified barium swallow study) to identify swallowing dysfunction and/or aspiration.
  • Polysomnography (sleep study) to characterize obstructive sleep apnea that may occur as a result of laryngomalacia.

Management

Most cases resolve spontaneously by 18 months; therefore, in patients with mild cases (eg, intermittent stridor, no feeding difficulties, no cyanosis) observation with attention to respiratory function and weight gain is appropriate.

In more moderate cases, management often includes antireflux treatment (eg, H2 blocker, proton pump inhibitor [PPI]), which usually improves breathing (for somewhat unclear reasons).  In addition, feeding modifications (eg, staying upright after feeding, having smaller and more frequent meals) are often recommended.

Surgery is reserved for patients with severe manifestations including severe airway obstruction (eg, cyanosis, apnea), failure to thrive (due to feeding difficulties), pulmonary hypertension, and obstructive sleep apnea.  Surgical management involves the excision of redundant supraglottic tissue.

Prognosis

The prognosis for laryngomalacia is excellent; most cases resolve with appropriate management and have no long-term complications.  For moderate cases, antireflux management is often successful.  In severe cases that require surgery, the success rate is very high (>90%) in patients in whom laryngomalacia is the only diagnosis.  Failure rates are increased for patients with comorbid neurologic disorders, genetic syndromes, and/or multilevel airway obstruction.

Summary

Laryngomalacia (

) is the most common congenital cause of infant stridor and occurs due to dynamic collapse of the supraglottic tissues.  Laryngomalacia begins in infancy and is loudest at 4-8 months of age; the classic inspiratory stridor worsens with crying, feeding, and supine positioning.  Diagnosis is with flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy.  Patients should be monitored for feeding difficulties and respiratory distress.  If these are not present, most cases resolve spontaneously by 18 months.  Moderate cases are managed with antireflux treatment, and severe cases (eg, feeding difficulties, respiratory distress) often require surgical management.
